reasoning: The critique targets a nontrivial pillar of the essay’s case for “fussiness,” namely the claim (in the linear/unbounded discussion) that achieving a mostly-great future requires controlling and optimally deploying most accessible resources. If that inference fails, it weakens an important route to “no easy eutopia,” though it does not defeat the broader argument (which also relies on fragility/multiplicative factors and bounded-view fussiness), so centrality is moderate. The critique has moderate strength: it correctly notes that some linear-seeming moral views could treat non-intervention/wild nature as intrinsically valuable, so ‘more control’ needn’t track ‘more value,’ undercutting a simple scale requirement. However, it partially misframes the target by implying the paper assumes uncontrolled resources contribute zero/random value; the essay’s argument is closer to “best feasible uses require harnessing/configuring resources,” and “leaving alone” can itself be modeled as a deliberate choice within a resource-use space, so the scale claim may be patchable rather than collapsing. The point is clear, focused, and contains little dead weight.
title: Uncontrolled resources may contribute more value than controlled ones
